results.title: James Bond, Meet Jeff Bezos: Amazon Makes $8.45 Billion Deal for MGM
results.abstract: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, while diminished, commanded a premium price, with Amazon seeking to bolster its crucial Prime membership offering.
results.byline: By Brooks Barnes, Nicole Sperling and Karen Weise

multimedia.caption: The 25th James Bond film, “No Time to Die,” is set for pandemic-delayed release in theaters on Oct. 8.

results.title: John Krasinski and the Tense Wait for ‘A Quiet Place Part II’
results.abstract: It’s been more than a year since the film he wrote and directed was originally set for release. Now, as the sequel to the 2018 hit reaches theaters, Hollywood is holding its breath.

multimedia.caption: Emily Blunt, Millicent Simmonds and John Krasinski, who said that as he waited for the film to come out, he spent the past year hovering “somewhere between optimism and naïveté.”
multimedia.copyright: Bryan Derballa for The New York Times

results.title: Australians Took Over Hollywood. Their Own Box Office Had to Wait.
results.abstract: In a rare feat, three locally made movies are the biggest hits in Australia, thanks in part to stars intent on homegrown stories. It only took a pandemic.

multimedia.caption: Jacob Junior Nayinggul, left, and Simon Baker in “High Ground,” about the massacres of Indigenous people in Australia.

results.title: John Cena Apologizes to China for Calling Taiwan a Country
results.abstract: Mr. Cena, a star of the newest “Fast and Furious” movie, posted a video apology in Mandarin, saying, “I’m really sorry. You have to understand that I love and respect China.”

results.title: How a Review Changed Both Sarah Silverman and Our Critic
results.abstract: A.O. Scott critiqued her approach to comedy in a 2005 movie. Now they sit down to talk about what he got right and wrong, and why owning up to mistakes is freeing.

multimedia.caption: Silverman said, “I never wrote stand-up by topic or by what’s taboo. I know it seems like I do, but I just don’t. That’s never been my process.”
multimedia.copyright: Photo Illustration by Chase Middleton for The New York Times

results.title: Kevin Spacey Cast in Italian Film After Being Sidelined in the U.S.
results.abstract: He will play a detective in the movie, directed by Franco Nero, in what is believed to be his first film since sexual assault allegations started surfacing in 2017.

multimedia.caption: Kevin Spacey will play a detective and is not a lead in the film, a producer said. Mr. Spacey has denied allegations of sexual assault that have been brought to court.

results.title: Happy Birthday, Bob Dylan, Our Most Underappreciated Comic
results.abstract: As he turns 80, don’t be fooled by his serious music. From the start, his work has been filled with a cockeyed humor that can range from corny jokes to dark wit.

multimedia.caption: Dylan in 1965, the year he released “On the Road Again,” a masterpiece of giddy nonsense.

results.title: 8 Ways a Modern Civil Rights Movement Moved the Culture
results.abstract: From music to movies, canceled podcasts to toppled monuments, our writers take stock of the culture we shared in the year after George Floyd’s murder.

results.title: Playing the Role of New York? Toronto. That View of Paris? It’s Montreal.
results.abstract: At the Venice Biennale, Canada examines its cities’ ability to stand in for television and film locations.

multimedia.caption: With green screens and special effects, the intersection of Dundas Street and Ossington Avenue in Toronto was reimagined as 1962 Baltimore for the 2017 film “The Shape of Water.”

results.title: ‘It’s Magic What We Do.’ Movie Theaters Get Starry-Eyed Once More.
results.abstract: The industry was decimated by the pandemic, with theaters shut across the country and new films delayed by Hollywood studios. But now cinemas are ready to fill up their seats again. Will audiences follow?

results.title: Dr. Aaron Stern, Who Enforced the Movie Ratings Code, Dies at 96
results.abstract: He was a New York psychiatrist who went to Hollywood to help lay down guidelines for sex and violence in films. Not everyone was pleased.

multimedia.caption: The psychiatrist Dr. Aaron Stern with his wife, Betty Lee Stern, in 2019. He wielded considerable power in the early 1970s when he was head of Hollywood’s movie rating board.

results.title: Stereotypes Are Rife Among Asian and Pacific Islander Film Roles, Study Finds
results.abstract: Two-thirds of characters reflect stereotypes, and just 3.4 percent of movies had leads or coleads who were Asians or Pacific Islanders, the study of 1,300 movies found.

multimedia.caption: Constance Wu, whose leading role in the movie “Hustlers” (2019) was praised as a good character in a new study. Not many Asians or Pacific Islanders star in movies, the study found.

results.title: Charles Grodin, Star of ‘Beethoven’ and ‘Heartbreak Kid,’ Dies at 86
results.abstract: A familiar face who was especially adept at deadpan comedy, he also appeared on Broadway in “Same Time, Next Year,” wrote books and had his own talk show.

multimedia.caption: The actor Charles Grodin with the title dog in the hit 1992 family movie “Beethoven.” “I don’t complain,” he said, “when the editor chooses my worst take because it’s the dog’s best take.”

results.title: Behind Every Hero or Villain, There Is Tech Support
results.abstract: Cutting-edge technology is often used in comics by the able assistants who fall under the trope “the guy in the chair.” But they are not always men and are not always helping the hero.

multimedia.caption: Noah Kuttler, a DC villain known as the Calculator, is a classic example of the comic book trope known as “the guy in the chair.”
